Indicates the the source in question is in early printing of the source. Early is defined here as roughly anything before 1800

remarks.p: This type/subtype combination is necessary because the are many primary and secondary sources that nevertheless appear in old and modern editions. It's important to make separate of primary manuscripts, primary early printings, primary modern editions, and secondary sources that are in early printings or in modern editions.

elementSpec.desc: A milestone marker used to mark the beginning of new folio.

remarks.p: This is a specific milestone for folio breaks. These are distinct from page breaks which can be either recto or verso. Folios always include two page breaks and typically four column breaks.

constraintSpec.desc: These constraints are used to require a place attribute when a when marginal attribute is used and to forbid a place attribute when an editorial note is used. The reasoning is that an editorial note is an intervention and a new creation, therefore there is no pre-existing place or location that it can be found. A marginal note is just the opposite, it has a physical place is a primary source witness, therefore that place needs to be recorded with a place attribute.

rule.report: This is a marginal note. This means that it is a note that exist in the primary source. Therefore it has a physical location that needs to be recorded.
This is an editorial note therefore no place attribute should be added.

valItem.desc: Any note supplied by modern editors not actually present in the primary source
A note present in the manuscript witness itself, but clear meant as annotation to the actual text. This note may either be in the same hand as the text or supplied by a latter reader.

attDef.desc: The subtype field should indicate what kind of marginal or editorial note this is. For Editorial notes there are two types: reference/quote identification or editorial explanation. For marginal notes there are generally three types: navigation, nameIdentification, summary

rule.report: This is a marginal note. Therefore these two types of subtypes are not appropriate
This is an editorial note. The only types of subtypes allowed are refIdentification and edExplanation.

valItem.desc: Any note supplied by modern editors to identify the source of a reference or quotation or both. This note should have a corresp attribute that points to the reference or quotation (or both that it is) identifying
A note that adds an editorial comment or explanation. Most anything that is not a reference identification should go here
An marginal note that says something like "prima conclusio" or "primus articulus" or "nota" should go here
Any marginal note that indicates the name of an author discussed in the text should go here
Any marginal note that provides navigational summaries should go here -- this is most visible in the sorb and mazarine transcription of Adam Wodeham's ordinatio

This is a del. element, which means that the lemma element should not be empty. The delete type indicates that the lemma visibile in the edited text is present but deleted in the manuscript witness

valItem.desc: indicates that the witness in question omits the designated lemma

indicates that the current lemma was added to the text by some sort of external imposition, either by the same scribe or a later scribe. There are two options here. If the lemma is empty this indicates that, at this point, the witness in question includes a word or phrase that was chosen not to be included the edited text. If a lemma is included then the addition means that the word identified in the lemma is present in the witness, but is inserted in some way (either in the margin or inter-linearly).
indicates that a segment of text was included in the text but then deleted. In such instances the lemma will most likely be left empty.

Indicates that the text indicated in the lemma is present in the witness in question but is deleted. In the case the edited text has decided that this deletion is an error and is not the best reading.
Indicates that the lemma text in the witness in question has been corrected from a previous form that has been deleted
